root.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 370 (includes Northern Yukaghir); not inherently intelligible with Northern Yukaghir. Ethnic population: 130. Language use: Home. Fluent speakers are 60 and older. Also use Russian [rus], especially those under 40. Those above 35 also use Yakut [sah]; those over 60 also use Even [eve].
child.alt-names: Forest Yukagir, Jukagir, Kolym, Kolyma, Odul, Southern Yukagir, Yukagir
child.geography: Russian Federation (Asia): Central Russia, Eastern Russia: Sakha Republic, upper Kolyma county, Nelemnoye and Zyryanka.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: May be distantly related to Altaic or Uralic. Population: 370 (includes Southern Yukaghir); not inherently intelligible with Southern Yukaghir. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language use: In Andryushkino there may be a few younger speakers (2007). Home. Older adults. Neutral or mildly positive attitudes. No sense of shared ethnic identity between the two Yukaghir varieties [yux] and [ykg]. Also use Chukchi [ckt], Russian [rus], or Yakut [sah]. Reindeer herdsmen and others also use Even [eve]. Language Development: Taught in primary schools through 4th grade in Andriushkino settlement; as an elective through 8th grade in Nelemnoye. Dictionary. Grammar.
child.alt-names: Jukagir, Northern Yukagir, Odul, Tundra, Tundre, Wadul, Yukagir
child.geography: Russian Federation (Asia): Central Russia, Eastern Russia: Sakha Republic, lower Kolyma county, Andryushkino and Kolymskoye.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
